text:
CAROLINE ELKINS: --gents. And welcome to HBS. It's a fantastic
afternoon for me as I'm here with three
fabulous students,

and we're going to have a
little conversation about FIELD, your experiences here on
campus, your experiences

in your immersions, and
Cape Town, and elsewhere, and Brazil. But first, a little bit about
the program for the folks

at home. How does that sound? So FIELD itself is
an acronym for Field Immersion Experiences for
Leadership, better known

as FIELD, and there
are two field classes. There's FIELD Foundations,
taught in the fall semester, and there's FIELD Global
Immersion, or FGI,

taught in the spring. And I've had a really
fortunate opportunity to teach both of them. So a little bit about this,
and just sort of conceptually,

I think here at
HBS what makes us so unique relative to
other business schools is that the university
leadership really

decided to make
this, this immersion experience, these hands
on, putting students

in the protagonist role to make
this a priority within the HBS curriculum. Nobody else has anything
quite like this.

And one shorthand way
of thinking about it is that these are-- if you
will-- soft skill classes.

We have hard skills and
finance and marketing. You guys know this. You have case after case.

But this is not a
case-based course. This is a course that's
going to challenge you-- and I suspect we're going
to hear from our three folks

to left here in a few minutes--
we're going to challenge you in unique ways. And there's often that saying
that goes your hard skills

are going to get you the
job, and your soft skills are going to make you a leader. And I think that's
really the ethos and underwrites
in a lot of this.

So what exactly do
these courses mean? Well, first of all,
FIELD Foundations, which is taught in
the fall, really

answers three, if you will,
building blocks to it. One is to develop
self-awareness, one is to develop
social awareness,

and the third part is
team effectiveness. In other words, how does
one get to know oneself,

how does one have
a sense of what's going on around them
with other individuals, and then how does
one work with teams.

And again, you are not
going to achieve this by reading how some fantastic
protagonist led somebody

to heroic victory at the SEC
or whatever the case may be, you're going to
learn this by doing.

And I think that's actually what
we're going to hear about it. It's one of the challenges
both as being a student, but also being as
a faculty member.

Faculty are intimately
involved with these courses. We teach them. In fact, our role is similar in
some ways to case-based courses

and in other ways
quite different. We have to also be willing to
lead from the front in what

can be some difficult and
challenging conversations as we explore how do we acquire
these soft skills.

So when these
students are involved in the interactive experiences,
they're often done,

not in our usual
case-based classes in Aldrich and elsewhere, but
we take a little field trip

about oh, about a 30-second
walk across campus to what are called the hives. We have movable
classrooms, and students

can work in teams on
experiential learning. We do simulations,
and yes, we sometimes come back to the
case rooms where

we debrief on certain
aspects of the course. And in many ways, this class
is in some ways a setup.

There's a narrative arc between
FIELD Foundations in the fall and FIELD Global
Immersion in the spring. Because FIELD Global Immersion
in the spring has students

actually take the skills
that they've learned and put them to action. In other words,
and in some ways,

we put them to action, but-- HBS being HBS, we're going
to up our game a little bit. We're going to put them into
action in a different context,

a different international
context, hence, FIELD Global Immersion. Our students, since this
course began in 2012,

MBA students have traveled
to some 33 cities, and it had been involved in
over 1,000 different projects

with global partner
organizations. So what exactly does this mean? What is FIELD? Is it just sort of a holiday?

You get to go to Cape
Town and Sao Pablo and-- not so much, actually. I mean, I've been the
faculty member there,

and these guys work hard. And hard work comes in
different kinds of ways, again, from case-based learning.

The building blocks
to this course is a combination of how do we
impart cultural intelligence

and contextual intelligence? How do we have students
understand a new place? Why is it that customers
and people locally

are going to make different
decisions in Boston? And seems rather obvious,
but it's actually something that's difficult to impart.

And along with that is, how do
we deal with teams, once again, team effectiveness. Because what happens
is, we divide all group.

So for example, I'm taking
a group to Kenya this year. There will be 84. They will be divided
into teams of six,

and they will be paired
with a global partner. And then if you
will, the glue that binds all of these
objectives together,

cultural intelligence,
contextual intelligence, and team effectiveness, is a
human design-centered project.

And with each global partner,
we will identify a project, and these teams of six will
work with this global partner

to develop what is
a B to C solution using human
design-centered thinking. So I've talked a lot
already, but hopefully,

laid the groundwork. I'm sure some of you
guys are like, oh, right. That's what we were
doing [? out ?] there. DENNIS: Now, I remember.

CAROLINE ELKINS:
Yeah, I remember. But really, there's nothing
that gives me greater pleasure than to be able to spend
some time with students

that I had formerly, and I
had all of you last year, and it really is, I think,
one of the amazing things

about HBS from a faculty
member's perspective is to be able to work
in these field classes

on frankly, in some ways, a
much different kind of level. I feel as though when I teach
these courses versus case

based, particularly when you
go, it's like real-world HBS. I take students to Cape
Town and now Nairobi.

You really get an opportunity
to know students beyond just the classroom environment. And I think, in
that sense-- and I'm

hoping that's
something a little bit that we can also talk about. What is it about
this program, both from a pedagogical standpoint,
from a personal standpoint,

but also from faculty-student
relationships standpoint in terms of really having
that kind of mentorship on the one hand, and
on the other hand,

for an old fogey like me,
where I get to really see the world through your eyes. So why don't I turn to my left.

Casey, why don't you tell us
a little bit about yourself, introduce yourself
to the crowd at home, and tell us about
where you're from

and what you've been up to here. CASEY: Yes. So my name is Casey. I am from New York, and
now a second year in HBS,

what we call an EC because
this is our elective curriculum year.

I was in consulting
before coming to HBS, and since
being here, I've

been a really active
member of Section B. I'm a member of the Retail
and Luxury Goods Club,

and exploring
different interests. It's the greatest
part about being here. CAROLINE ELKINS: Excellent. Dennis.

DENNIS: I'm Dennis. I grew up in Singapore,
and I spent my, probably eight years before
business school in New York.

And I did technology
investing back in New York. Here, I do a bunch of things. I'm involved in the Tech
Club and the Investment Club.

I'm doing and
independent project, which you can do at HBS on
subscription businesses, which is really cool.

And we'll talk about this
later, but I went to Brazil, spent some time in Sao
Paulo for my project

and also traveled
through the Amazon, which was a awesome time too. CAROLINE ELKINS: That
sounds pretty great.

Kristen. KRISTEN: Hi, my name is Kristen. I'm originally from New
Jersey, but prior to HBS,

I lived in almost
every corner of the US as part of the US military. I was a captain in the Army
flying black-op helicopters

just prior to school. For my global
immersion assignment, I went to Bangkok,
Thailand, which

was an awesome experience. Here at school, I'm one
of the co-presidents of the Armed Forces
Alumni Association,

also involved in
the Technology Club, and really having a great time
exploring the different options

here at HBS. One of my favorite things
about this second year of the elective
curriculum is I'm

cross registered at both
the Kennedy School and MIT, which I think is just another
little tidbit about how

global of an experience you
get to have here at HBS. CAROLINE ELKINS:
Fantastic, guys. Well, why don't we start a
little bit with the fall term.

We can break it
up for these guys, because there really
are two classes, but they're complementary. And a lot of the skill
sets we're trying to impart

are complementary to each other. But if you think back,
dust off the memory to RC, which is the
required curriculum

year, your first year here. In what ways did you find FIELD
Foundations and the courses

with FIELD Foundations
complementing the case-method
courses that you had?

CASEY: I can get us started. CAROLINE ELKINS: Sure. CASEY: So if I think about
my biggest learning moments

in case-method
discussions and in FIELD, it was whenever I
was put on the spot or put in a position that put
a little bit of pressure on me

and helped me
understand what are my instinctive thoughts, what
are my instinctive behaviors. And in a case-method
discussion, that tends to be,

how do I break down a
problem really quickly? What is the first
thing that I notice? But in FIELD, it was what
do I do when I'm nervous,

when I'm under pressure? How does that come
off to other people? I remember doing
simulations of negotiations,

of crisis management type
of things with Everest, which I'm sure we'll talk about. CAROLINE ELKINS:
Let's pause on that.

So Everest is-- there's
a simulation where you're with a team, right all of you? And Everest, where
you have to try

to get to the top
with your team, and each member of
the Everest team is given a certain
amount of information.

And as a faculty
member, I can always predict this like clockwork. One of you guys are going to
sort of make it to the top,

and the rest is not so good. And it's also videotaped. CASEY: Yes. CAROLINE ELKINS: And
you get to see yourself.

KRISTEN: Yeah, I think
that really draws light on one of the biggest
differences between the case method and the FIELD
experience is the case method,

you read a case, you
discuss the case, and then you close the case. It's over. You leave, and do
something different or go on to the next case.

But in FIELD Foundations,
almost all of our experiences are an experience,
and then we always

debrief and reflect
on it afterwards. So I think there were two if not
three different exercises that

were filmed. So you go through
this experience, you see how you
react, and then you're forced to actually watch
yourself on film afterwards

and see how the rest
of the world sees you and really reflect on your
actions in more than just

an immediate way. CASEY: And others
watch it with you, and say, remember
when you did that? This is how that made me feel.

This is how it seemed,
and it's really powerful. DENNIS: It's also one
of the first chances we got to really work as a team.

If you think about the
first RC curriculum, you do a lot of finance
and marketing and stuff

like that in class,
but you never really are put
into a group of six and say, hey, let these
various backgrounds

and various personalities
mix and what comes out the other end. So I thought that was
the most intense part. CAROLINE ELKINS: Let's talk
about that a little bit. What's the good,
the bad, the ugly

of being able to--
because these are really, I think, one of the things
that are, from a teaching perspective, both
exhilarating and also

where one has to really
as a faculty member be attuned to 90 plus
students in the classroom.

Because on the
one hand, you know that there's going to be
failure, and on the other hand,

you want to impart the
skills for students to be able to pick themselves
up individually and as teams, but also to give guidance
in those debriefs.

So the good, the bad, the
ugly about Everest and being filmed in this kind of stuff. What were your
takeaways from that?

Because I think that's
one of a crucial-- it can give us by way of
example crucial difference and also some of the
things that you learned.

And we'll pause on that
and later on talk about FGI and see where you
came from there. DENNIS: Well, let me start.

So first of all, caveat, Carrie
here was our a FIELD professor, so I have to say what
I'm going to say.

No, I'm kidding. CAROLINE ELKINS: I paid
him a lot of money. DENNIS: No, I think FIELD
did a tremendous job

at preparing us to build
long-term relationships with the people that
we were meeting at HBS.

And I think we had this thing
in the first semester where we laid out all the different
flags of the various countries

that our classmates, our
section mates were from. And obviously, FIELD
is there to say, look.

Look at that. This is the level of diversity
you have in this classroom. You guys are going to spend so
much time with these 90 people.

Getting the right
answer is important, but that's not the
most important. It's about how you guys, over
time, trust each other, build

this family, and all that. And I thought Everest was
the step one of that, where you still have a few people.

You're comparing between
selfish goals and team goals, and some people want to get
to the top of the mountain. But then as you keep
doing these exercises,

you realize is that really
the most important thing, or is there something
else more important? KRISTEN: I think
what surprised me

the most is the dialogue
that stemmed out of the Everest exercise. There was the exercise itself
and then the formal debrief,

but in my group, at least,
there were three or four conversations with different
members of the team that

spawned off of that
experience in regards to relationship building,
in regards to leadership,

actual feedback that was
solicited from different team members, two different
team members. And there were
tears and emotions

that I have never seen in
a classroom environment before that stemmed
out of that exercise.

That was really
surprising, but in an awesome developmental way. CAROLINE ELKINS: Terrific.

Casey. CASEY: I totally
agree with that, and I think one of
the hardest things was that happened right at
the beginning of school.

So we were basically
all strangers as we were going through these
really emotional exercises and being critiqued and
critiquing ourselves publicly.

And I think it was
really interesting-- the beginning of what has been
a two-year lesson and will be

a lifelong lesson of how do you
get input about others and see them in tough situations
and learn about them,

but also allow them to progress
and change and grow and balance that first impression with
the two year down the road

or the
however-many-year-down-the-road impression. I think that's something that
has really stuck with me, just

the lesson that you might see
some really, really, really strong actions and hear some
strong words from people that

may or may not be
indicative of where they are at the end of
their HBS experience. KRISTEN: Totally. DENNIS: Yeah. CAROLINE ELKINS: Yeah, I
think it's interesting for me

to hear all this from you guys. I had the perspective of
the bird's eye perspective. You sort of see it
all playing out.

But I think that I do-- and
then we'll move on to FGI, but to what degree do you
feel FIELD Foundations--

and it's a good segue into FBI-- really, explodes
some of the myth about whether it's HBS or
your typical business school.

That it's hard charging,
cut throat, as opposed to-- and I obviously
teach this course,

but my goal and observation
to which students go on this kind of journey
over the course of the RC,

and frankly, over the course of
two years of really embracing this notion, first of all, that
your section is your squad.

Look to your left,
look to your right, you've got everybody's back,
and building on that ethos.

But then you get to
Everest and suddenly, it's like, oh, maybe not so much. But it's this
incremental experience--

two steps forward,
one step back. But to what degree does
Foundations lend itself

to building those kinds
of teams and that sense, not just of camaraderie
here, but also of how to lead

when you get out of here? Do you feel that it helps
to accomplish some of that? KRISTEN: Yeah.

I think the fact
that it's not always the same group of six people
that you are organized

with in the different FIELD
Foundations experiences, I mean, there was the Everest
exercise we keep referring to,

but we had an
experience that we had to build the tallest tower
possible with marshmallows

and spaghetti. Yeah, the identity mapping. So we set up small tables
with different groups.

So there is a philosophy
that someone told me when I was a first year that
was the second year at the time

that said, every time she
met someone in her section, just immediately we
tend to make judgments. That's just human
nature, about people.

And she was the same. She would always put
somebody into a box. But then she would
have an experience

with them at a round table
or at the Everest exercise or a conversation that
spawned from something

that happened in class. And without fail, they
would jump out of that box. She could not put people
in this little box,

these snapfire judgments that
we tend to make about people. And I think these experiences
and these different types

of small teams and
then the reflection that we're forced to have
afterwards really prevents that

from happening. And I think to your point
of leading on the backside, I think it really force
me anyways, when I go out

into the business
world, I'll meet someone make a snapfire judgment that
is natural in human nature,

but really to step back,
reflect and say, OK, why did they do that,
or what else is there

to this individual that maybe
just needs some drawing out? CAROLINE ELKINS: Yeah, and
I think it's on that point

that faculty get this very
interesting-- because everyone keeps referring to reflections. I know sort of a joke,
reflect, reflect, reflect.

After you're done
with these exercises, it's not just that
we debrief in class, but you actually have to
do written reflections with the idea.

And it's a very strong,
pedagogical philosophy at HBS that reflection is crucial
to us internalizing

some of the concepts
that we're teaching. And to your point, Kristen, from
a faculty member standpoint,

the reflections
are extraordinary. I read 90 of them
every week, and you learn about individuals
who could be pigeonholed

as the banker woman
or the military guy or the marketing person or the--

and those just are completely
within a week gone. And the journeys that
people have taken,

the struggles that they have,
the ways in which they're looking to be the
leader they want to be but can't quite get
there quite yet.

And I think it's one
of the magics of HBS that we're all in
on this together. And with that in mind,
being in on it together,

so we're in Boston,
FIELD Foundations, and then suddenly we're
going up our game, and we're going to
go to Cape Town.

We're going to go to Sao Paulo. We're going to go
off to the Far East.

Can you talk a little bit
about this transition? Between the two courses, what
made FIELD Global Immersion

different than
FIELD Foundations? Might be in a good way
for us to start into this. What do you think, Dennis?

Start us off. DENNIS: I can start us off. Well, for one you, get
a team, and now you have to work the team for--

CAROLINE ELKINS: So
explain the team. What's the team? DENNIS: So you get placed. You don't really get to pick. You get placed on a
team of six people, all

from different sections. CAROLINE ELKINS: So
this is totally new. DENNIS: Totally new. CAROLINE ELKINS:
It mixes it all up. KRISTEN: You pick your location. DENNIS: Right. You do pick your location.

So you pick your location. You might not get
your first choice, but I got my first choice.

And then once you
have that location, they put that team together. And my guess-- and you
correct me if I'm wrong--

is that this team has put
together with intention, not like a random-- CAROLINE ELKINS: There's
a very complex algorithm. DENNIS: Right.

There's a complex algorithm-- CAROLINE ELKINS:
Actually, we just throw everything up in the air. DENNIS: --and everything at HBS.

That could have been it too. KRISTEN: I don't think
that's an algorithm. DENNIS: Complex algorithm,
we'll stick with that. And this team becomes your
squad for the next four or five

months. And it's great. You need to start thinking about
things in a very different way. It's like, OK, well, there's
no point putting on a front

because that front
quickly goes away when you spend that much
time with each other. You need to figure out
who is going to lead

or is it going to be a
rotational leadership. The lessons that you learn
in the first semester and not only in FIELD but in LEAD
and other classes that you're

immediately applying,
week one of FGI. CAROLINE ELKINS: Give us
some examples from LEAD, and tell these
guys what LEAD is.

What is LEAD? DENNIS: You want to take that? I'm happy to-- you can go. If you're like me,
you lead the team on.

CAROLINE ELKINS:
Aye, aye, Captain. DENNIS: Aye, aye, captain. KRISTEN: Yeah. So being in positions
always of formal authority

in the military, it was a very
different experience for me to be in a team of six that
no one is the formal authority

figure, and you have
to really figure out how we were going
to work in a team. And I think one of the--
did we learn in FIELD

or LEAD, the team launch? DENNIS: That was LEAD. CAROLINE ELKINS: That was me. DENNIS: That was you? CAROLINE ELKINS: That was me. KRISTEN: We talked
about it in both. DENNIS: Yeah, we talked
about it in both.

That's good. CAROLINE ELKINS:
We'll split it up. We're not competitive here. DENNIS: Yeah, that's right. KRISTEN: But there's
a scenario, or there's

a philosophy called team launch,
and when you get together with a team, what
you have to do, lay everything out on the
table what are your priorities?

What are you trying
to get out of this? Something we talked
about is, what is your ideal day look like?

And that really draws out
what people's priorities are. I'm an early riser. I like to stay up late. And really launching the
team from the very beginning

and laying all of the must
haves and definitely don't dos on the table, for
our team, at least that

went to Bangkok, really
early on prevented a lot of conflicts that
could have arisen later

because we all knew where
each other stood from day one. CAROLINE ELKINS: What
do you think, Casey?

CASEY: I think, I mean, I
totally agree with everything. The team aspect just
becomes much more real

when you are working
together on a trip. On location, it
feel like it's 24/7,

and that is completely different
than FIELD Foundations. But also you have
a global partner. You have a client that
you're working for.

CAROLINE ELKINS: Yeah,
tell me about that. Who's your global
partner in Cape Town? CASEY: So we had an
awesome global partner in Cape Town called to The
Training Room Online, TTRO,

and they are a
nonprofit that's seeking to change the game in
education by way of technology.

So we did a project
for them that was all focused around how
do we get parents to engage with their child's education.

And that is complicated by
so many factors universally, but also specific to Cape
Town and to South Africa.

And then a factor
that's, in a way, almost introduced by TTRO in
that as you digitize education

more, are you making
parents feel ostracized? Do you make them feel like they
can't actually help and support

in the way that they might
have in a few generations ago? So we were helping them
tackle all of those problems,

and we worked on it
for months from Boston, so we're navigating
as you guys know, you were navigating
time differences

and trying to get to know each
other, get to know the client, but without being
in the same place. And then getting on
the ground and knowing

we have very limited
time here, we have to-- like you always say--
squeeze every second out

of every moment
while we're there. CAROLINE ELKINS:
Because I did make you hike up Table Mountain. CASEY: Yes. First thing in the morning
before going straight

to the client. CAROLINE ELKINS: Before
going straight to the client. CASEY: Yes, which was awesome. CAROLINE ELKINS:
Yeah, we did, really.

CASEY: Twice. CAROLINE ELKINS: We went
up Table Mountain twice and [? Brian ?]
said, really, I mean, I think the idea of
FIELD Global Immersion

is also once you've done
the heavy lifting here, you're there for 10 days. And my view is the bar
of excellence is up here,

and we are going to squeeze
every ounce of being where we are in that location,
that you're not

going to get that time back. And I never wanted
students come back and say, I could have been in Dallas,
or I could have been in--

and so, yeah, this
poor group had to suffer with going
up Table Mountain. DENNIS: It's part of FGI. You can't complete
it without that.

KRISTEN: So in Bangkok, I woke
up first thing in the morning and got on a water taxi that
was right outside our hotel

and went to a couple of
temples in the morning and watched the sun rise
over the temples in Bangkok and then got back on the
water taxi, went to the hotel,

showered, and met my FGI
group and then met our client later on in the afternoon.

I mean, you don't
get that in Dallas. CAROLINE ELKINS: You don't. And I think that the
ethos of really-- and this

gets back to the
building blocks. There's the team
effectiveness part, which is what you so eloquently
described with the team

launch and the cultural and
contextual intelligence, which are the glue binding it together
as this human-centered design

experience, but that cultural
contextual is hugely important. But getting to the team
part, look, I mean,

I do joke sometimes. It's like real-world HBS. I mean, we prepare
you as much as we can.

But surely, there
are some things that you weren't prepared
for until you're literally-- and this gets back to why being
literally in the protagonist

position versus
reading about it makes all the difference in learning. So tell us. Give us some
examples of anything

that comes to mind that you
just learned because you did. You were learning by doing.

KRISTEN: So I think we focused
a lot during the train up to FGI about the methodology itself.

And we talked a lot
about design thinking and exactly how we were
going to execute that.

And my client for
our project was a mall group called Siam
Piwat in Bangkok, like I said.

And they had three
different malls that was basically one conglomerate. They had a new mall
called Siam Discovery

on one side of
their conglomerate, and they wanted to figure
out why traffic wasn't moving

from one side of
their mall, which was Siam Piwat,
the touristy side,

over to their new feature
of Siam Discovery. And we were able to
go through the process

as we were trying to do
interviews while we were out on the ground, and we
walked through the Pru here in Boston to look
at traffic flow and malls

in the US. And what we discovered
through the process is that the client, once we
did our final presentation,

was looking for lots of ideas. They didn't so much care about
the process we went through

while we were doing it,
which is the learning aspect of it for us.

But when we did our final
presentation to the client, they just wanted tons
and tons of ideas

and where we came up with
these ideas from just our life experiences. And I think that that was a
big surprise in drawing out

from the client over the
course of the project what they are looking for, not what
you think they're looking for.

DENNIS: Maybe I'll tackle that
question from the team aspect and what went, I would say, not
as smoothly as I would like.

I think everyone has very
different expectations of what A, they're
supposed to deliver,

and B, how much work
they want to put. Because when you're there for
24/7, like what Casey said,

you could be doing a lot. You could be effectively doing
a year's work in three weeks, or you could do three
weeks' work in three weeks.

So the difference in
expectation had to really be calibrated over time. So there was an iterative
team launch process

it was a difficult part. The other piece is
not really knowing, like Kristen mentioned,
what exactly we're
